Message.Title: Largest “Stomach” In The U.S.A. Digests Food Waste, Spits Out Biogas Fuel For Trucks
Message.Msg: Largest “Stomach” In The U.S.A. Digests Food Waste, Spits Out Biogas Fuel For Trucks December 15, 2012 Tina Casey The company CleanWorld has just started up what could be described as a gigantic man-made digestive system at a garbage transfer station in Sacramento, California. When it’s fully expanded, the Sacramento Biodigester will be the largest facility of its kind in the U.S., capable of gobbling up about 100 tons of food waste per day and converting it into enough natural gas fuel to replace 1 million gallons of conventional diesel fuel per year — and that’s just for starters. The Skinny on the Sacramento Biodigester The new digester basically employs the

No rise in mass killings And yet those who study mass shootings say they are not becoming more common. "There is no pattern, there is no increase," says criminologist James Allen Fox of Boston's Northeastern University, who has been studying the subject since the 1980s, spurred by a rash of mass shootings in post offices. The random mass shootings that get the most media attention are the rarest, Fox says. Most people who die of bullet wounds knew the identity of their killer. Society moves on, he says, because of our ability to distance ourselves from the horror of the day, and because people believe that these tragedies are "one of the unfortunate prices we pay for our freedoms." Grant Duwe, a criminologist with the Minnesota Department of Corrections who has written a history of mass murders in America, said that while mass shootings rose between the 1960s and the 1990s, they actually dropped in the 2000s. And mass killings actually reached their peak in 1929, according to his data. He estimates that there were 32 in the 1980s, 42 in the 1990s and 26 in the first decade of the century. Chances of being killed in a mass shooting, he says, are probably no greater than being struck by lightning.

"Chances of being killed in a mass shooting, he says, are probably no greater than being struck by lightning." It would be much simpler to just dispense with all appeals in criminal cases and put the convict to death - and cheaper too. The chances of executing an innocent would be statistically low, but that is not acceptable. Your principles are flawed and contemptible... This how a civilized society, like Germany, handles things: you have to have a firearms ownership license (Waffenbesitzkarte) to buy each gun. To get one you must meet the following criteria: § 4 WaffG - age of majority § 5 WaffG - trustworthiness § 6 WaffG - personal adequacy § 7 WaffG - expert knowledge § 8 WaffG - necessity In a barbaric society you just show up with a suitcase of money at a gunshop or show and can leave like Rambo...

Message.Title: The Philosophy of Right
Message.Msg: More remedial instruction for the confused libertarians: Read Natural Law of the Sciences of State in outline, Elements of the Philosophy of Right, Hegel, 1820. The book is a textbook of lectures given by Hegel as University Professor instructing the ruling class of Germany in good methods of governance. Most of his ideas were not original to him but just a distillation of Prussian methods of governance. In Hegel's words: "(you are) the universal class...the class in which the consciousness of Right and the undeveloped intelligence of the mass of the people is found." The students were the nobles, the princes, and the sons of wealthy businessmen across Germany, not a second rate rabble. Modern Progressives and "technocrats" aspire to such as well, as well they should. Such philosophy indicates a very large role for government in a RIGHT WING society...40-50% of society dominated by government and "technocrats" for well over a century is a matter of course. It was not for nothing that Americans opened all German intellectual property rights to pillage by American corporations just after World War II, thus allowing them to extract technology worth at least $10 billion (7 or 8% of the value of all American stocks at the time), and thousands of German scientists to fill the yawning gap of technical knowledge in America at the time. If limited government matched the German big government model such transfers would not have been necessary. The Progressives did copy the philosophy outlined by Hegel, and his students' philosophy, as much as they could, but they were fought by the libertarian strain from start to finish...So what was created was a curious hybrid that was smart and advanced in many ways, possessed of immense natural resource, but capable of putting a fool like Coolidge, or W in office. The American Civil War, which boiled down to a class of ideology along such lines of the role of government (and especially states rights), did not eliminate all the libertarian small government view.
